poem:
The Dean's Feline Gospel  

In the nave, a tail sways  
where faith meets fur—  
sermons shared  
wide as the world,  
soft whiskers brush  
pulpit's edge,  
broadcast alive;  
curiosity creeps  
through sacred light,  
claws knead wisdom  
into Sunday silence,  
God whispers  
under paws, unseen.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Very Rev Robert Willis obituary If it is true that God works in mysterious ways his wonders to perform, then the intervention of his cats into online sermons broadcast during the Covid pandemic in 2020 helped to propel the Very Rev Robert Willis, dean of Canterbury Cathedral, to an appreciative worldwide audience thought to number millions. Willis, who has died suddenly aged 77 in post-Canterbury retirement, while a resident fellow of Berkeley Divinity School". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: The Very Rev Robert Willis obituary If it is true that God works in mysterious ways his wonders to perform, then the intervention of his cats into online sermons broadcast during the Covid pandemic in 2020 helped to propel the Very Rev Robert Willis, dean of Canterbury Cathedral, to an appreciative worldwide audience thought to number millions. Willis, who has died suddenly aged 77 in post-Canterbury retirement, while a resident fellow of Berkeley Divinity School
